intro: Gynochthodes retropila, commonly known as the backward-piled gynochthodes, is a rare and little-studied plant species belonging to the family Myrtaceae. It is characterized by its unique floral structure, which features a bilaterally symmetrical arrangement of stamens and carpels. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as rainforests or dense undergrowth. Its leaves are lanceolate and have a smooth, waxy surface, which helps reduce water loss in humid conditions. Due to its limited distribution and fragile habitat, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
